comments.commentBody:
Astonishing that a reader here would suggest that an increase in interest rates "is the correct Fed answer now."

Economists like to argue about theories and too often misquote Adam Smith with opposite content and meaning of his words.

What is fundamental about this series of interest rate increases is that a vast percentage of the 99.9%--workers, pensioners, and those on Social Sec--will be paying more to Bank of America, et al, and just like in Brazil, those in the financial industry and the upper levels of the hierarchy will be getting more income. And Janet Yellen has such a big smile: for who? Not me, I hope, since I'll be paying more.

KJ - Yes, our parents, veterans of the Great Depression, gave us some very good lessons.  One of them, for me, was to never have a credit card, only a debit card.  Thus, usurious rates don't apply.  Another was to turn out the lights when leaving the room.  I follow both lessons to this day.

Whatever the Fed does is by and for the banks, and the rich, not for the rest of us.  So this posturing, this adjustment,  is meaningless.  Let's see real action, like increasing Social Security payments to seniors barely getting by, or former students bent over double by the interest on their college loans, or tax increases on the rich.  Please, President Trump, pay attention to Main Street, as you said you would.  Main Street is waiting.

Yeah, and Obama doubled the national debt from 10 to 20 trillion to do that.  Some achievement.  Remember any of those dastardly bankers from Lehman Brothers or Bear Stearns going to jail for their swindling during Obama's reign?  Me neither.  Just partisan nonsense.

The writer of this article, probably inadvertently, revealed one elementary fact which dispositvely proves that American Capitalism will defeat and destroy the happiness of a huge proportion of the American people.

The writer remarked, "The unemployment rate, at 4.8 percent in January, is in a range Fed officials regard as healthy..."

An enormous proportion of Americans are not earning enough money. Although an unemployment rate of 4.8 percent might sound low, the number does not count people who are out of work and not looking for work, or those who aren't working full time, or those people who are "independent contractors," who are often really just unemployed people trying to make a living by stringing together short-tem projects, a day here, a couple of days there, etc.

But this level of unemployment, according to the Fed, is healthy, i.e., it is good for capitalism.

Therefore, capitalism is incongruous with human liberation as making a decent living is pre-requisite for same.

The super rich love it when the ordinary Joe is faced with foreclosure...the wealthy can add to their portfolios, then charge rent to the newly "homeless."

What a sickness these greedy banks/investors/vultures have!

There is a great deal of misinformed opinion about the Fed abroad in the land and amply evidenced by some comments here.
I was privileged to serve seven years as a Director of a Branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. My service there brought me in contact with Janet Yellen. I can say without fear of contradiction that informed observers know her to be an incredibly knowledgeable, strategic thinker and, incidentally, a woman with a wonderful sense of humor.
The structure of the Federal Reserve System is sensitive to the variations in regional economies...each District is an entity unto itself and forwards its regional conditions into an analysis mechanism that weighs every significant sector of the economy locally and nationally. What is now...what can we expect? The Fed Economists are exceptionally talented.
Don't get me wrong...I have a lot of things I can criticize about the Fed. But, on balance, they are the best device we could hop for in turbulent economic times.
If the OMC (Open Market Committee) believes that maintaining the balance of full employment and controllable inflation is approaching a turning point requiring a rate change, they have my confidence.
If this increase is ineffective, Trump can blame Yellen as a hold-out from Obama.  Anyway it goes, it's a win for him.

Closing in on full employment? Do these people know that Mr. Trump won precisely because there's much unemployment? MAYBE the 4.5 figure is not as accurate as all claim it to be. These guys simply believe that there is a "healthy" level of unemployment because if it were lower, wages would go up, companies' costs would also go up and there would be more inflation. Creepy.
Not particularly relevant to the Fed and interest rates....but one of the more coherent discussions about the personal and corporate tax structure and the overall economy!

The Fed should leave the interest rate alone after this hike for at least 12 months. More than one interest rate change per year is  both unnecessary and disruptive.  Keep the banks regulated instead. Wouldn't it be amazing to see the Fed refuse to loan to a financial institution it deemed too risky? That would be doing the American people and economy a far greater favor then just pulling your puppet strings.

Gee. I bet the trump voters are saying "we knew he could do it within a couple of weeks of being elected!
Duh!ald
I think you have that backwards Charles. It's Trump who keeps declaring everything is a disaster!

It takes 8-10 years at least to recover from a recession induced by a financial crisis. Bill Clinton said in 2009 that the economy wouldn't see a full recovery until 2017 or so.

A president should not be credited nor blamed for the economic performance under his watch. That said, Barack Obama stepped into armageddon, and along with Ben Bernanke and an assist from Hank Paulson, kept the economy from ruin and set it on a course that has put us where we are now. It is now time for the DOA Congress to play its part.

It should also be noted that, during the campaign, Trump warned that the equity markets were one small interest rate hike from being slaughtered. Now after less than 6 weeks in office, he is taking credit for its rise.
Usually, as rates rise, we see a bump in financial activity, as buyers want to borrow at low rates and lenders begin marketing credit in anticipation of higher returns.

Until wages catch up for the average person I think this is a bad idea. Face it how many of you are making more than 15 dollars an hour or more? Just because the economy is getting better Dump Trump will surely screw it up with tax breaks and deregulations for the super rich. History does repeat itself and it will again when it comes to an economy that mirrors the 2006 and 1929.
Wow, an actual coherent statement from the Chair of the Fed Reserve. What happened to the confusing wrapped in a riddle style statements issued by the former Federal Reserve Chair?

The potential return over a year if it were a CD would be $800 or 5.3% of $15,000, which today is a lot, but not 16%.  But the return is for opening a single account, not an account every three months. The return of a single $200 payment over a year would be 1.3%.  Don't get Ron Lieber excited.  Banks and shadow banks are looking for customers in anticipation of future sales of credit.

This is insane. GDP is growing at an annual rate of 1.6% and the Fed is concerned about inflation? (China’s GDP last year grew 6.7%.) And don’t believe the official unemployment rate of 4.8%. We’ve got Ph.D.s flipping burgers and the homeless begging for a meal on every corner.
One thing we do know...if interest rates rise, growth goes negative. Oh, and what happened to all those houses that were foreclosed as a result of the 2008-2009 crash (you know, the one where Wall Street denizens got richer).
Some see a ray of sunshine while others can never get passed the doom and gloom.

I surely don't like a lying government official or politician, even though I'll readily admit that most of those in both categories have refined the art of lying to the point that in all but the cases of an easily exposed lie, they get away with it most of the time...call it misdirection, inarticulate, shading the truth, obfuscating or whatever other cheat word you like.

However, I'll also admit that as an independent voter (read that as non-partisan) I am quite surprised at the left's seeming attribution of virtually all that's wrong with America and the new Administration as being the result of Russian intrigue when much more obvious and much more likely causes are available.

I recall once in, I think, the second presidential debate in 2016 when Hillary was asked directly about the corruption implicit in her private e-mail server, a topic utterly separate and distinct from any Russian meddling in the election. Instantly and seeming seamlessly practiced, she pivoted, didn't answer the question and denounced the Russians. That was made it pretty clear to me that Russian meddling was a straw man erected as a diversion by the DNC and the Clinton campaign.

I don't think much has changed since then in the left's "Russia did it all" meme. And, I think it's more likely that the left is simply using it to beat Trump and his Administration over the head with and delay the implementation of his campaign promises.

Over-zealousness invites suspicion.

LF

Why should she have wasted valuable debate time reiterating a dead issue?  Hillary's emails, including those illegal hacks by Russians, were made completely public and investigated (allowing us all to learn great new risotto techniques but nothing actionable), while Trump has refused to even release his taxes, much less make his/his admin's dealings with Russia transparent. Trump's people even lie about them under oath.  I assume if you are non-partisan you would at least want these investigations to be equivalent.
If all these meetings were so  trivial And innocent, why do the Trumpies keep lying about them?
Truth is relative.

i have a solution that helps. whenever i see him, i
pretend jeff sessions is
arte johnson on the old "laugh-in" tv show.
for now, it works.
oops.  i meant henry gibson.  sorry arte.
